sections.section: This tutorial shows how LoopBack Request nodes can be used to retrieve and add data to a database.  The example uses an application which provides two message flows: one for retrieving documents and one for adding documents to a NoSQL Cloudant database.
It also shows how connectors from the LoopBack framework can be used to carry this out.
The tutorial can be extended to create flows that retrieve data from one database (ie MongoDB), then performs some operation on the data before storing it in another database (ie Cloudant).

sections.section: When you click Import, an application will be created in your workspace: LoopBack.

create.msgflow and retrieve.msgflow each implement a single message flow with a HTTPInput, LoopBackRequest node and HTTPReply node. In this tutorial, these two applications will run in the same integration server. With additional configuration they can run on different servers or even on different machines.
The difference between the two message flows is quite small. The HTTP Input for create.msgflow has a path suffix '/create', where as the one for retrieve.msgflow is '/retrieve'.
The LoopBackRequest node for create.msgflow has the 'create' operation selected, where as the one for retrieve.msgflow is 'retrieve'.
These are explained in more detail when you move on to the Prepare tab, along with setup steps you need to complete before running the flows.

sections.section: Look inside application Loopback. There are two flows that should be visible retrieve and create. The LoopBackRequest nodes in both flows are configured to reference a data source name of 'CLOUDANT', a LoopBack object of 'share_price' and a security identity of CLOUDANT_SEC_ID, to avoid putting in plaintext credentials.
In both cases, a HTTP call is used with the LoopBackRequest node to contact the Cloudant database and perform some action, which can be viewed on the HTTP Reply.
To allow the message flows to connect to the Cloudant database, there are some additional steps.

details.details: Sign into bluemix and create a new database.

Then make sure that there is a datasources.json file in the connectors/loopback folder (located in the IIB folder ie /Program Files/IBM/IIB/10.0.0.7/connectors/loopback), otherwise create one. This is where the details for backend systems are stored, which is what we need for the cloudant connection.
Install the loopback connector for cloudant: npm install loopback-connector-cloudant â€“save.
Go back to Bluemix and find the username and password that are listed for the Cloudant service.
Use mqsisetdbparamas to like these credentials to the username and password that were just found.
Set the config for the request node by adding a stanza to the datasources.json file:{ 'CLOUDANT': {'database': 'share_price','name': 'CLOUDANT','port': 443,'connector': 'cloudant'}}

sections.section: The application providing LoopBackRequest nodes are built into a BAR file loopback_nodes.bar. Deploy these now, using the link on the right of this page. Once you have done that, move on to the Run tab to exercise the flows and see them working.

sections.section: Use the create.msgflow in application Loopback to run this tutorial. You should have already deployed the loopback_nodes.bar to the default integration server on your TESTNODE.

details.details: Open create.msgflow, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy and start testing the flow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.
Choose the input message (ie {'companyID':'103','company':'Barclays PLC','phone': '0800400100','price':171}) JSON message, and click Send. Your request message is sent to the HTTP input node.

A response should be shown, which includes an id that has been given to the document (ie youâ€™ll get a reply with the id that the database has created for it ie {'id':'111111111111111111','companyID':'103','company':'Barclays PLC','phone':'0800400100','price':171})
After you close the dialog, the path taken through the messageflow is highlighted. Click on the message icon on each connection to see how the tree is updated by each node.
Now that the database has been added to, when it is quieried it will be able to return an entry.
Open retrieve.msgflow, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy and start testing the flow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.
Choose the input message (ie just '' will get all the items in the database) JSON message, and click Send. Your request message is sent to the HTTP input node.
A response should be shown, which lists the item that you've added previously
After you close the dialog, the path taken through the messageflow is highlighted. Click on the message icon on each connection to see how the tree is updated by each node.
